[SPELLING]: "pay" used incorrectly (e.g., "is paymaster," "are pay five cents")
[SYNTAX]: Occasional overly complex sentence structures (e.g., "Across the Atlantic...")

[STRUCTURE]: Slight abruptness between introductory chapter and biographical narrative (lacks transitional bridge)
[TRANSITION]: Minor disjointedness in paragraph jumps within "THE BOY PRINTER" (e.g., shift from school to travel)

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect verb tense consistency (e.g., "may I went to work")

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between scenes (e.g., Michigan to Chicago)

[LEXICON]: Use of archaic terms (e.g., "shoddy," "hand-jogging") may hinder modern readability.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, outdated sentence structures (e.g., "You, in turn, are adorned...").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt scene shifts (e.g., from boss’s house to workplace, to historical printing details) without clear connectors.
[STRUCTURE]: Episodic, loosely connected anecdotes (e.g., Goudy introduction feels tangential to preceding narrative).

[SPELLING]: "is was printed" (redundant verb in "an edition of Puck is was printed")
[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing in "plucking me long before I am ripe" (metaphorical but slightly unclear)
[LEXICON]: Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., "You design a cover... His salary offer is flattering")

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from World’s Fair context to Herbert Stone’s publishing venture
[STRUCTURE]: Late introduction of typography critique feels disconnected from preceding narrative
[CLARITY]: Overloaded paragraphs (e.g., mixing World’s Fair, studio details, and job offers without clear links)

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect verb forms ("mighted be used", "shoulded possess", "have give us").
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally convoluted sentence structures (e.g., lengthy descriptions without clear breaks).

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt insertion of the quotation ("When the tide...") without contextual lead-in.
[STRUCTURE]: List-like enumeration of influences (e.g., Kelmscott Press, Yellow Book) feels loosely integrated.

[SYNTAX]: Awkward dialogue phrasing (e.g., repeated "why," stuttered responses).
[LEXICON]: Occasionally overly formal tone in conversational exchanges.
[STRUCTURE]: Infrequent long, complex sentences disrupting natural flow.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from business failure narrative to "INTERLUDE IN NEW YORK" without clear bridging.
[STRUCTURE]: Non-sequential jumps between historical context, personal description, and dialogue scene.
[CLARITY]: Minor ambiguity in pacing between reflective commentary and vivid scene-setting.

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect verb form ("you woulded be given")
[SYNTAX]: Abrupt transition between sentences (e.g., layout request to art editorship offer)
[LEXICON]: Occasionally formal or archaic vocabulary (e.g., "pseudo-Benjamin Franklin dress")

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt chapter transitions (e.g., "NEW FIELDS" to "THE MAGAZINE WORLD") without clear linking
[TRANSITION]: Minor disconnects between paragraphs (e.g., shift from Collier’s Thanksgiving issue to hiring backstory)

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect verb form ("woulded" instead of "would have") in "Additional sales woulded tax the plant..."

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from Collier’s projects to Hearst’s work without transitional context;
[STRUCTURE]: Tangential mention of "Spoils" and "Launcelot and the Ladies" without clear relevance to surrounding narrative.

[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing (e.g., "there being an obvious change") and overly complex sentences.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures in paragraphs (e.g., long compound sentences with multiple clauses).
